awd_titl_txt: Downward Gamma Ray Showers from Natural Lightning
awd_abstract_narration:
Lightning is known to produce Terrestrial Gamma Flashes (TGFs) which are bursts of high-energy gamma rays that last up to a few milliseconds.  How the gamma rays are produced and whether they can tell us more about lightning has been an active research area for a couple of decades.  Recently, a research team from the particle astrophysics community teamed with lightning researchers to obtain new observations of gamma rays using the Telescope Array Surface Detector (TASD) in Utah, which is a 700 square kilometer cosmic ray observatory.  This award will continue these investigations into the generation of TGFs.  The main societal impact from this award will be through the increased understanding of TGFs, which may provide additional information on lightning, a well-known natural hazard.  The project will also help to provide public outreach opportunities to enhance the scientific literacy of the population and provide training opportunities for the next generation of scientists.


The research team will follow up on their prior award which demonstrated that downward gamma ray showers are produced at the beginning of negative cloud-to-ground lightning.  This observation was made in southwestern Utah using a combination of the TASD and Lightning Mapping Array (LMA) stations.  Now that this phenomenon has been discovered, the research team plans to address specific questions about the mechanisms responsible for gamma ray production and characterization of the types of lightning events in which TGFs occur.  New observations will be conducted with the addition of a high-speed broadband VHF interferometer and fast electric field change sensor.  Concurrently, the TASD is expanding in size, leading to more events that can potentially be observed.  The specific objectives of the proposal include:  1) Simultaneous observation of downward gamma flash events with TASD, LMA, Slow- and Fast Antennas and broadband interferometer to significantly increase the sample size of downward TGFs, 2) Determine conclusively via fast-E spheric measurements whether the observed gamma flashes have the expected correlation with Initial Breakdown Pulses (IBP) and Energetic Intracloud Pulses (EIP), and 3) Continue advances in modeling of gamma showers and the TASD response, and use these models to further characterize shower source size, altitude, and gamma ray angular distribution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project NSF/AGS-1844306 is the second in a series of awards given for the study of gamma ray production in lightning using a preexisting (and partially NSF-funded) cosmic ray detector (The Telescope Array Surface Detector or TASD). The earliest results of these studies included the first definitive observations of downward gamma ray showers associated with the leader stage of cloud-to-ground lightning, which were found to be consistent with low-fluence versions of the Terrestrial Gamma Flash (TGF) phenomenon. TGFs were primarily detected via overhead satellites prior to the present experiment, while we have added new new information about TGFs near their initiation threshold.

Intellectual Merit:

Under the current award, we have seen both an expansion in the number of downward TGFs detected and the instrumentation used in their study. The TASD is in the process of a fourfold expansion in its areal coverage, from 700 square kilometers to nearly 2,800 square kilometers. We have installed two high-speed broadband interferometers (INTF and INTF2) and four additional Lightning Mapping Array (LMA) stations to enhance coverage in the RF band. With the installation of INTF, we developed a new technique to localize the TGF production within the lightning at sub-microsecond timescales and with spatial resolutions measured in meters. 

Most recently, we have added high-speed video cameras, photometers and static electric field mills to  the Telescope Array Lightning Observatory's suite of lightning detection instruments. We have already recorded for the first time the optical counterparts of downward-TGF events, with a paper forthcoming. A complete list of publications to-date follows:

* THE BURSTS OF HIGH ENERGY EVENTS OBSERVED BY THE TELESCOPE ARRAY SURFACE DETECTOR, R.U. Abbasi et al., Physics Letters A 381 pp. 2565-2572 (2017).

* GAMMA-RAY SHOWERS OBSERVED AT GROUND LEVEL IN COINCIDENCE WITH DOWNWARD LIGHTNING LEADERS, R.U. Abbasi et al., J. Geophys. Res. 123 6864-6879 (2018), DOI: 10.1029/2017JD027931.

* OBSERVATION OF THE ORIGIN OF DOWNWARD TERRESTRIAL GAMMA-RAY FLASHES, J. Belz et al., J. Geophys. Res. 125 e2019JD031940 (2020). DOI:10.1029/2019JD031940. arXiv:2009.14327.

* OBSERVATION OF VARIATIONS IN COSMIC RAY SINGLE COUNT RATES DURING THUNDERSTORMS AND IMPLICATIONS FOR LARGE-SCALE ELECTRIC FIELD CHANGES, R.U. Abbasi et al., Phys. Rev. D, 105 (2022). e-Print:2111.09962.

* FIRST HIGH-SPEED CAMERA OBSERVATIONS OF THE OPTICAL COUNTERPART OF A TERRESTRIAL GAMMA-RAY FLASH, R.U. Abbasi et al., submitted to Geophys. Res. Lett. (2022). e-Print: 2205.05115.

Broader Impacts:

The combination of the TASD and lighting detection array is a unique synergy between the NSF divisions of Particle Astrophysics and Physical and Dynamic Meteorology. This synergy has produced ? at relatively modest cost ? remarkable advances that would not have been possible by either agency acting on its own.

The project also supports the work of undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, thus contributing to the education and technical training of the next generation of researchers. Outreach is coordinated with the ASPIRE project, supported by the same NSF grants as the Telescope Array. ASPIRE produces a set of web-based lessons and lab activities with an astrophysical theme, as well as direct outreach to local teachers and students in the form of presentations and workshops for groups underrepresented in the sciences and rural schools in Utah and Montana.
